6. Apply Clue 6: for those 3 numbers, arrange their digits from least to greatest and check whether that rearrangement is prime; only 617 passes, so the mystery number is 617. [Rudimentary]']

Question:
Ranger Cadet Bu Star has just been given the task of moving the five cases of Park Pop soda at the Weiss Pavilion to the Wirth Pavilion, which is 5 miles away. For transportation, Bu must use a MoJoPed, a moped which runs on Park Pop. It can carry, at most, its rider and 25 bottles of soda, i.e., one case in its cargo carrier and one bottle in its fuel tank. It gets one mile to the bottle and is currently empty; it will only move under Pop power. How many unopened bottles can Bu deliver to the second pavilion?
Comments to triflers:
The bottles and cases are hi-tech, so there are no concerns about theft or littering. They can stay parked or be discarded anywhere. Yes, the constant rate of fuel use is unreal, and yes, of course, I am asking for the maximum number of bottles!
Hint: There are hints in the comments to triflers and in the title.
Human Solution:
80
To achieve this surprising result, Bu must first take the five cases, one at a time, and park them at a point along the route 2 5/18 miles from the Weiss Pavilion. This takes 9 trips of 2 5/18 miles (5 advancing trips interspersed with 4 return trips) for a total of 20.5 miles traveled (9 * 2 5/18 = 20.5) and 20.5 bottles of soda used. Cadet Star now has 99.5 bottles of soda. (5 * 24 - 20.5 = 120 - 20.5 = 99.5) He puts 3.5 of these aside and redistributes the other 96 to completely fill four cases. With one less case to move, Bu will now make 2 fewer trips. The 3.5 bottles set aside are used to move the four cases the next 1/2 mile toward the Wirth Pavilion.   After this, the Wirth Pavilion is just 2 2/9 miles away ( 5 - 2 5/18 - 9/18 = 2 4/18 ). Next, he travels 15 5/9 miles (7 * 2 2/9) using 15 5/9 bottles of soda to complete his trip. The ranger cadet delivers 80 bottles to the pavilion and has 4/9 of a Park Pop to spare. (96 - 15 5/9 = 80 4/9)
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Decide to create a stash 2 5⁄18 miles from the Weiss Pavilion and move all five cases to that point before proceeding farther.  (Creative)  

2. Work out that carrying the five cases to the stash point takes 9 trips (5 outward, 4 return), a travel distance of 20.5 miles, and therefore consumes 20.5 bottles of soda as fuel.  (Rudimentary)  

3. Compute the bottles left at the stash point: 120 − 20.5 = 99.5 bottles.  (Rudimentary)  

4. Realize that if 3.5 bottles are set aside for fuel and the remaining 96 bottles are consolidated into four full cases, one bulky case can be discarded, cutting the number of future trips.  (Creative)  

5. Use the reserved 3.5 bottles to move the four full cases an additional ½-mile, a distance chosen so the remainder of the journey has a convenient length for the new load.  (Creative)  

6. Calculate the distance still to go after this advance: 5 − (2 5⁄18 + ½) = 2 2⁄9 miles.  (Rudimentary)  

7. Determine that moving the four cases the final 2 2⁄9 miles takes 7 trips, a travel distance of 15 5⁄9 miles, and therefore consumes 15 5⁄9 bottles of soda.  (Rudimentary)  

8. Subtract the last fuel use from the 96 bottles being carried to get 80 unopened bottles delivered (with 4⁄9 of a bottle left over).  (Rudimentary)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 8  
Creative ', ' 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Decide to create a stash 2 5⁄18 miles from the Weiss Pavilion and move all five cases to that point before proceeding farther.  (Creative)  

2. Work out that carrying the five cases to the stash point takes 9 trips (5 outward, 4 return), a travel distance of 20.5 miles, and therefore consumes 20.5 bottles of soda as fuel.  (Rudimentary)  

3. Compute the bottles left at the stash point: 120 − 20.5 = 99.5 bottles.  (Rudimentary)  

4. Realize that if 3.5 bottles are set aside for fuel and the remaining 96 bottles are consolidated into four full cases, one bulky case can be discarded, cutting the number of future trips.  (Creative)  

5. Use the reserved 3.5 bottles to move the four full cases an additional ½-mile, a distance chosen so the remainder of the journey has a convenient length for the new load.  (Creative)  

6. Calculate the distance still to go after this advance: 5 − (2 5⁄18 + ½) = 2 2⁄9 miles.  (Rudimentary)  

7. Determine that moving the four cases the final 2 2⁄9 miles takes 7 trips, a travel distance of 15 5⁄9 miles, and therefore consumes 15 5⁄9 bottles of soda.  (Rudimentary)  

8. Subtract the last fuel use from the 96 bottles being carried to get 80 unopened bottles delivered (with 4⁄9 of a bottle left over).  (Rudimentary)']

Question:
Henry is a new civil engineer, and is charged with planning the laying of a new type of ultra-rigid rails that expand only one inch per mile of length in temperature extremes.  Henry's plan calls for the tracks (each of which is one mile in length) to be laid end-to-end with no gap between them, pinned to the ground at every other juncture, as shown below:
v_______ _______vv_______ _______v
Henry's boss sees the plan and says, "You fool!  What about when the tracks expand?"
Henry replies, "The expansion will only be an inch over the whole mile length.  If the tracks buckle, it will only be by an inch or two at most.  The trains will certainly have no trouble bumping over these buckles."
Henry's boss says, "You're fired."  Why was the boss so critical?
Hint: Would Pythagoras have the same plan?
Human Solution: The rise in the middle of the tracks would have been much greater than Henry surmised.  Using the Pythagorean Theorem, you will have a triangle with a base of one mile (or 63,360 inches), and a hypotenuse of one mile plus one inch (or 63,361 inches). To find the height, take the square root of (the square of the base minus the square of the hypotenuse). SQRT((63,361)^2 - (63,360)^2) = 355.98 inches, or over 29 feet!
Response:
Total Step Count: 6  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Model the situation: When a one-mile rail is fixed at both ends and lengthens by one inch, the only way it can fit is by buckling upward, which can be idealized as two equal straight segments forming an isosceles triangle whose base is the original one-mile distance and whose equal sides are the expanded rail length.  (Creative)  
2. Convert the one-mile base and the expanded length into the same units: 1 mile = 63 360 in, expanded length = 63 360 in + 1 in = 63 361 in.  (Rudimentary)  
3. Identify the right triangle and set up the Pythagorean relation: height² = (hypotenuse)² − (base)².  (Rudimentary)  
4. Compute the numerical value: height = √[(63 361)² − (63 360)²] ≈ 355.98 in.  (Rudimentary)  
5. Convert the height to feet: 355.98 in ÷ 12 ≈ 29.7 ft.  (Rudimentary)  
6. Draw the conclusion: the buckle would rise roughly 30 ft, vastly larger than “an inch or two,” justifying the boss’s criticism.  (Rudimentary)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 6  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Model the situation: When a one-mile rail is fixed at both ends and lengthens by one inch, the only way it can fit is by buckling upward, which can be idealized as two equal straight segments forming an isosceles triangle whose base is the original one-mile distance and whose equal sides are the expanded rail length.  (Creative)  
2. Convert the one-mile base and the expanded length into the same units: 1 mile = 63 360 in, expanded length = 63 360 in + 1 in = 63 361 in.  (Rudimentary)  
3. Identify the right triangle and set up the Pythagorean relation: height² = (hypotenuse)² − (base)².  (Rudimentary)  
4. Compute the numerical value: height = √[(63 361)² − (63 360)²] ≈ 355.98 in.  (Rudimentary)  
5. Convert the height to feet: 355.98 in ÷ 12 ≈ 29.7 ft.  (Rudimentary)  
6. Draw the conclusion: the buckle would rise roughly 30 ft, vastly larger than “an inch or two,” justifying the boss’s criticism.  (Rudimentary)']

Question:
Jill is helping plan her family's new patio. It will be an irregular hexagon. They will use 1-foot-square stone tiles. Here are her notes.
1. The perimeter of the deck is outlined by ABCDEF.
2. Line AB is against the house. It is 16 feet long.
3. AF is perpendicular to AB.
4.AF and BC are parallel.
5.BC and AF are each 6 feet long.
6.Points F and C are connected by FC; FC is parallel to AB.
7.Points G and H are on FC.
8.FG and HC are each 4 feet long.
9. ED is 8 feet long. It is parallel to AB.
10. DH is perpendicular to HC. It is 4 feet long.
11. EG is perpendicular to FG. It is 4 feet long.
12. Angle BCD is 135 degrees.
13. Angle AFE is 135 degrees.
If they order 6 more tiles than they would ideally need (to allow for breakage), how many patio tiles should they order?
Assume that tiles can be cut cleanly so that any leftover pieces can be used for other parts of the deck.
Hint: Draw the figure; divide it into sections which it is easier to find the areas of
Human Solution:
The area of the deck is 144 square feet. They will need 150 tiles.
Explanation
The area of ABCF is 96 square feet.
The area of DEGH is 32 square feet.
The area of CDH and EFG combined is 16 square feet. You will be able to complete these sections with 8 tiles each after cutting four of the tiles in half diagonally.
The total area is 144 square feet. Allowing 6 extra tiles for breakage brings the order to 150 tiles.
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Recognize from the given parallel and perpendicular conditions that ABCF is a rectangle whose sides are AB = 16 ft and BC = AF = 6 ft. (Creative)  
2. Compute the area of rectangle ABCF: 16 ft × 6 ft = 96 ft². (Rudimentary)  
3. Notice that DEGH forms a second rectangle because ED ∥ AB, DH ⟂ HC, EG ⟂ FG, and both DH and EG are 4 ft, giving this rectangle dimensions 8 ft (ED) by 4 ft. (Creative)  
4. Compute the area of rectangle DEGH: 8 ft × 4 ft = 32 ft². (Rudimentary)  
5. Identify the remaining two corner regions, ΔCDH and ΔEFG, as congruent right-isosceles triangles with legs 4 ft (formed by the 4-ft perpendiculars), so each has area ½·4·4 = 8 ft², for a combined 16 ft². (Creative)  
6. Add the three sub-areas: 96 ft² + 32 ft² + 16 ft² = 144 ft² total patio area. (Rudimentary)  
7. Convert area to the number of 1-ft² tiles required: 144 ft² → 144 tiles. (Rudimentary)  
8. Include six extra tiles for possible breakage: 144 + 6 = 150 tiles to be ordered. (Rudimentary)

['Total Step Count: 8  
Creative ', ' 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Recognize from the given parallel and perpendicular conditions that ABCF is a rectangle whose sides are AB = 16 ft and BC = AF = 6 ft. (Creative)  
2. Compute the area of rectangle ABCF: 16 ft × 6 ft = 96 ft². (Rudimentary)  
3. Notice that DEGH forms a second rectangle because ED ∥ AB, DH ⟂ HC, EG ⟂ FG, and both DH and EG are 4 ft, giving this rectangle dimensions 8 ft (ED) by 4 ft. (Creative)  
4. Compute the area of rectangle DEGH: 8 ft × 4 ft = 32 ft². (Rudimentary)  
5. Identify the remaining two corner regions, ΔCDH and ΔEFG, as congruent right-isosceles triangles with legs 4 ft (formed by the 4-ft perpendiculars), so each has area ½·4·4 = 8 ft², for a combined 16 ft². (Creative)  
6. Add the three sub-areas: 96 ft² + 32 ft² + 16 ft² = 144 ft² total patio area. (Rudimentary)  
7. Convert area to the number of 1-ft² tiles required: 144 ft² → 144 tiles. (Rudimentary)  
8. Include six extra tiles for possible breakage: 144 + 6 = 150 tiles to be ordered. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
Kevin and Smith are in charge of counting people who get on and off the lift. They take turns riding to the top floor and back down, counting as they go. After three such trips each morning noon and evening, there is an average taken.
The hotel manager wants to know the days average.
1.On Smith's noon trip there were 32 fewer people than in his morning count.
2.Kevin counted a total of 122 in the morning and noon counts, just one higher than his evening count, but 24 more than Smith's Evening count.
3.Kevin's morning count is the same as Smith's average.
4.Kevin's evening count was 37 more than Smith's morning count.
Hint: Clue 2 gives most of the information needed to get started.
Human Solution:
Set up mathematical equations Morning Noon Evening Total Ave
Kevin  78       44      121     243   81
Smith  84       52       98     234   78
Response:
Total Step Count: 10  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 8  

Steps:  
1. Introduce six variables to stand for every unknown count:  
   Km, Kn, Ke = Kevin’s morning, noon, evening counts;  
   Sm, Sn, Se = Smith’s morning, noon, evening counts. (R)  

2. Convert Statement 1 (“Smith’s noon trip had 32 fewer people than his morning trip”) into the equation  
   Sn = Sm – 32. (R)  

3. Convert Statement 2 into three simultaneous equations:  
   a) Km + Kn = 122 (Kevin’s morning-plus-noon total)  
   b) Ke = Km + Kn – 1  (that total is 1 more than his evening count)  
   c) Se = Km + Kn – 24 (that total is 24 more than Smith’s evening count). (R)  

4. Convert Statement 3 (“Kevin’s morning count equals Smith’s average”) into  
   Km = (Sm + Sn + Se)/3.  
   Recognising that the word “average” ties three separate counts into one concise equation is the key modelling insight here. (C)  

5. Convert Statement 4 (“Kevin’s evening count was 37 more than Smith’s morning count”) into  
   Ke = Sm + 37. (R)  

6. Substitute Sn = Sm – 32 from Step 2 into the average equation from Step 4, reducing Sn out of the system. (R)  

7. Use the two expressions for Ke (from Steps 3b and 5) to eliminate Ke, and use the expression for Se from Step 3c to eliminate Se; the system is now in only Km, Kn, Sm. (R)  

8. Combine the reduced equations algebraically to solve for Sm; then back-solve successively for Ke, Se, Kn, and finally Sn. (R)  

9. Plug the solved numerical values into all original equations to confirm consistency, guaranteeing that every condition is met. (C)  

10. Compute each person’s three-trip total and divide by 3 to display the requested table:  
    Kevin – 78, 44, 121 → 243 total → 81 average;  
    Smith – 84, 52, 98  → 234 total → 78 average. (R)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 10  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 8  

Steps:  
1. Introduce six variables to stand for every unknown count:  
   Km, Kn, Ke = Kevin’s morning, noon, evening counts;  
   Sm, Sn, Se = Smith’s morning, noon, evening counts. (R)  

2. Convert Statement 1 (“Smith’s noon trip had 32 fewer people than his morning trip”) into the equation  
   Sn = Sm – 32. (R)  

3. Convert Statement 2 into three simultaneous equations:  
   a) Km + Kn = 122 (Kevin’s morning-plus-noon total)  
   b) Ke = Km + Kn – 1  (that total is 1 more than his evening count)  
   c) Se = Km + Kn – 24 (that total is 24 more than Smith’s evening count). (R)  

4. Convert Statement 3 (“Kevin’s morning count equals Smith’s average”) into  
   Km = (Sm + Sn + Se)/3.  
   Recognising that the word “average” ties three separate counts into one concise equation is the key modelling insight here. (C)  

5. Convert Statement 4 (“Kevin’s evening count was 37 more than Smith’s morning count”) into  
   Ke = Sm + 37. (R)  

6. Substitute Sn = Sm – 32 from Step 2 into the average equation from Step 4, reducing Sn out of the system. (R)  

7. Use the two expressions for Ke (from Steps 3b and 5) to eliminate Ke, and use the expression for Se from Step 3c to eliminate Se; the system is now in only Km, Kn, Sm. (R)  

8. Combine the reduced equations algebraically to solve for Sm; then back-solve successively for Ke, Se, Kn, and finally Sn. (R)  

9. Plug the solved numerical values into all original equations to confirm consistency, guaranteeing that every condition is met. (C)  

10. Compute each person’s three-trip total and divide by 3 to display the requested table:  
    Kevin – 78, 44, 121 → 243 total → 81 average;  
    Smith – 84, 52, 98  → 234 total → 78 average. (R)']

Question:
Take a five-digit number and reverse it. Subtract the original number from the reversed number and you are left with 33957.
How many different possibilities does the original number have?
Hint: Work from the first and last digits.
Human Solution:
Suppose that the original number is abcde. Then edcba-abcde=33957.
Since e>a, we must have e=a+3 and therefore d=b+4, and c can be any digit.
a can be 1 to 6 and e 4 to 9, b can be 0 to 5 and d 4 to 9, each pair has 6 possibilities, and c has 10 possibilities.
Therefore, the original number has 6*6*10=360 different possibilities.
Response:
Total Step Count: 4  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. Model the situation with digit notation: let the original five-digit number be written as abcde; its reverse is edcba, and set up the equation edcba − abcde = 33957. (Rudimentary)  

2. Examine the digit-by-digit subtraction implied by the difference 33957 to deduce the relations between corresponding digits, obtaining e = a + 3, d = b + 4, and c unrestricted. (Creative)  

3. Apply the digit constraints 0 ≤ digit ≤ 9 to each relation: a can be 1–6 with matching e 4–9, and b can be 0–5 with matching d 4–9; c can be any digit 0–9. (Rudimentary)  

4. Count the combinations: 6 choices for (a,e), 6 choices for (b,d), and 10 choices for c, giving 6 × 6 × 10 = 360 possible original numbers. (Rudimentary)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 4  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. Model the situation with digit notation: let the original five-digit number be written as abcde; its reverse is edcba, and set up the equation edcba − abcde = 33957. (Rudimentary)  

2. Examine the digit-by-digit subtraction implied by the difference 33957 to deduce the relations between corresponding digits, obtaining e = a + 3, d = b + 4, and c unrestricted. (Creative)  

3. Apply the digit constraints 0 ≤ digit ≤ 9 to each relation: a can be 1–6 with matching e 4–9, and b can be 0–5 with matching d 4–9; c can be any digit 0–9. (Rudimentary)  

4. Count the combinations: 6 choices for (a,e), 6 choices for (b,d), and 10 choices for c, giving 6 × 6 × 10 = 360 possible original numbers. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
You have two identical ropes and three mice.  Each mouse bites off the rope at a different biting speed.  All three biting speeds are constant.
Mouse(A) bites off one rope in 60 minutes.
Mouse(B) bites off one rope in 90 minutes.
Mouse(C) bites off one rope in 180 minutes.
You do not have any time or distance measuring tools and the length of the rope is unknown.  How can you measure 75 minutes?
Hint: Set distance and time relations and equations
Human Solution:
Mark the two ropes as Rope(A) and Rope(B).
1. Let Mouse(A) and Mouse(C) start biting off Rope(A) at the same time, starting each from  one end (moving in opposite directions).  At the same time, let Mouse(B) start biting off Rope(B).
Finding relative speeds between Mouse(A) and Mouse(C):
Distance = Speed * Time
X = S(A) * 60, where S(A) is biting speed for Mouse(A) and X is Rope(A) length
X = S(C) * 180, where S(C) is biting speed for Mouse(C) and X is Rope(A) length
Solving the two above equations gives:
S(A)/S(C) = 3:1, which means that for each 3 units Mouse(A) will move, Mouse (C) will move 1 unit.
Moving in opposite directions (assume Mouse(A) from left to right and Mouse(C) from right to left), the two mice will meet after Mouse(A) bites off three times what Mouse(C) bit off, which divides Rope(A) length in to 4 units.
Mouse(A) bitten off portion = 3/4 X (where X is Rope(A) length)
Mouse(C) bitten off portion = 1/4 X
Finding the time spent before Rope(A) is completely bitten off by the two mice:
If Mouse(A) needs  60 minutes to bite off X, How many minutes are needed to bite off 3/4 X?
Minutes needed = 3/4 * 60 = 45 minutes are needed to fully bite off Rope(A) by Mouse(A) and Mouse(C).  At that point in time, Mouse(B) would have bitten off exactly half the length of Rope(B) (needing 90 minutes to bite off the full rope), and needs an additional 45 minutes to bite off the remaining rope half.
2. Let Mouse(B) continue biting off Rope(B) and make Mouse(C) start biting off the other end of Rope(B).
Finding relative speeds between Mouse(B) and Mouse(C):
Distance = Speed * Time
X/2 = S(B) * 90, where S(B) is biting speed for Mouse(B) and X/2 is the remaining half of Rope(B) length
X/2 = S(C) * 180, where S(C) is biting speed for Mouse(C) and X/2 is the remaining half of Rope(B) length
Solving the two above equations gives:
S(B)/S(C) = 2:1, which means that for each 2 units Mouse(B) will move, Mouse(C) will move 1 unit.
Moving in opposite directions (assume Mouse(B) from left to right and Mouse(C) from right to left), the two mice will meet after Mouse(B) bites off two times what Mouse(C) bit off, which divides the remaining half of Rope(B) length to 3 units.
Mouse(B) bitten off portion = 2/3 * X/2 = X/3
Mouse(C) bitten off portion = 1/3 * X/2 = X/6
Finding the time spent before the remaining half of Rope(B) is completely bitten off by the two mice:
If Mouse(B) needs  90 minutes to bite off X, how many minutes are needed to bite off X/3?
Minutes needed = 1/3 * 90 = 30 minutes are needed to fully bite off the remaining half of Rope(B) by Mouse(B) and Mouse(C).
At that point in time, 75 minutes would have passed (45 minutes consumed from biting off Rope(A) and another 30 minutes consumed from biting off Rope(B)).
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Label the two ropes as Rope A and Rope B so their progress can be tracked. (Rudimentary)  

2. At t = 0 start Mouse A and Mouse C on opposite ends of Rope A while Mouse B starts on one end of Rope B. (Creative)  

3. Calculate the speed ratio of Mouse A to Mouse C (3 : 1) and deduce that together they will finish Rope A in 45 minutes (A eats ¾, C eats ¼). (Rudimentary)  

4. Note that those 45 minutes leave Mouse B exactly halfway through Rope B, since it needs 90 minutes for a full rope. (Rudimentary)  

5. Now place Mouse C on the opposite end of the remaining half of Rope B while Mouse B continues from his end. (Creative)  

6. Compute the speed ratio of Mouse B to Mouse C (2 : 1) and find that the remaining half of Rope B is finished in 30 minutes. (Rudimentary)  

7. Combine the two intervals (45 minutes + 30 minutes) to see that exactly 75 minutes have elapsed when Rope B is completely eaten; use that instant as the desired 75-minute mark. (Rudimentary)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 7  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Label the two ropes as Rope A and Rope B so their progress can be tracked. (Rudimentary)  

2. At t = 0 start Mouse A and Mouse C on opposite ends of Rope A while Mouse B starts on one end of Rope B. (Creative)  

3. Calculate the speed ratio of Mouse A to Mouse C (3 : 1) and deduce that together they will finish Rope A in 45 minutes (A eats ¾, C eats ¼). (Rudimentary)  

4. Note that those 45 minutes leave Mouse B exactly halfway through Rope B, since it needs 90 minutes for a full rope. (Rudimentary)  

5. Now place Mouse C on the opposite end of the remaining half of Rope B while Mouse B continues from his end. (Creative)  

6. Compute the speed ratio of Mouse B to Mouse C (2 : 1) and find that the remaining half of Rope B is finished in 30 minutes. (Rudimentary)  

7. Combine the two intervals (45 minutes + 30 minutes) to see that exactly 75 minutes have elapsed when Rope B is completely eaten; use that instant as the desired 75-minute mark. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
Rob the robot went to the candy-store to buy some candies. He found his favorite gums in front of him, in packages of 225 gums in each.
Though extremely intelligent, he is still a robot, thus capable of using only 1's and 0's.
What is the minimum number of gums that Rob ate that day if he finished all of his packages, and the number of gums contained nothing but 1's and 0's?
Oh yes, and you can't cheat and use binary notation.  The answer is in base 10, but still only uses 1's and 0's.
Hint: Think of the factors of 225, and kids, don't try this at home (or you would suffer from a severe stomach ache).
Human Solution:
11,111,111,100
This contains nine ones, so it is divisible by 9, and two 0's at the end, so it is divisible by 25.
Response:
Total Step Count: 6  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Note that 225 = 9 × 25, so the sought‐after number must satisfy the divisibility tests for both 9 and 25.  
2. (Creative) Observe that the only way a number using only the digits 0 and 1 can be divisible by 25 is for its last two digits to be 00.  
3. (Rudimentary) Conclude that every candidate therefore looks like “a string of 1’s followed by 00,” i.e. 11…1100.  
4. (Rudimentary) Apply the divisibility rule for 9: the sum of the digits must be a multiple of 9.  For a number of the form 11…1100, this sum equals the count k of 1’s.  
5. (Rudimentary) Choose the smallest positive multiple of 9 for k, namely k = 9, which gives nine 1’s.  
6. (Rudimentary) Form the number 11111111100, verify it is divisible by both 9 and 25, and note that any larger multiple of 9 would produce a longer (and hence larger) number, so this is minimal.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 6  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Note that 225 = 9 × 25, so the sought‐after number must satisfy the divisibility tests for both 9 and 25.  
2. (Creative) Observe that the only way a number using only the digits 0 and 1 can be divisible by 25 is for its last two digits to be 00.  
3. (Rudimentary) Conclude that every candidate therefore looks like “a string of 1’s followed by 00,” i.e. 11…1100.  
4. (Rudimentary) Apply the divisibility rule for 9: the sum of the digits must be a multiple of 9.  For a number of the form 11…1100, this sum equals the count k of 1’s.  
5. (Rudimentary) Choose the smallest positive multiple of 9 for k, namely k = 9, which gives nine 1’s.  
6. (Rudimentary) Form the number 11111111100, verify it is divisible by both 9 and 25, and note that any larger multiple of 9 would produce a longer (and hence larger) number, so this is minimal.']

Question:
If 3**5 = 27 but 5**3 = 35
4++8 = 20 but 8++4 = 16
Then what is the result of (8**7)++9?
Hint: Both use some combination of multiplication and addition; relate the change in digits on each side with the differences in the outputs
Human Solution:
The result is 106.
For the operator **, you add 4 to the second number and then multiply, so a**b = a * (b + 4)
and a++b = a + (b * 2)
So therefore (8**7) ++9 = (8*(7 + 4)) ++ 9
= 88++9
= 88 + (9 *2)
= 88 + 18
= 106
Response:
Total Step Count: 4  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 2  

Steps:  
1. From the examples 3**5 = 27 and 5**3 = 35, infer a general rule for the ** operator: a**b = a × (b + 4). (Creative)  
2. From the examples 4++8 = 20 and 8++4 = 16, infer a general rule for the ++ operator: a++b = a + (2 × b). (Creative)  
3. Apply the ** rule to compute 8**7: 8 × (7 + 4) = 8 × 11 = 88. (Rudimentary)  
4. Apply the ++ rule to compute 88++9: 88 + (2 × 9) = 88 + 18 = 106, giving the final result. (Rudimentary)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 4  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 2  

Steps:  
1. From the examples 3**5 = 27 and 5**3 = 35, infer a general rule for the ** operator: a**b = a × (b + 4). (Creative)  
2. From the examples 4++8 = 20 and 8++4 = 16, infer a general rule for the ++ operator: a++b = a + (2 × b). (Creative)  
3. Apply the ** rule to compute 8**7: 8 × (7 + 4) = 8 × 11 = 88. (Rudimentary)  
4. Apply the ++ rule to compute 88++9: 88 + (2 × 9) = 88 + 18 = 106, giving the final result. (Rudimentary)']

Question: Arrange the digits 1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 4, 4, 5, and 7 to form a single fraction that equals 1/11
Hint: The last digit must be the same
Human Solution: Note that the last digit must be the same--then try to group numbers together to reasonably find possibilities of divisibility by 11 One solutions is 4321/47531=1/11
Response:
Total Step Count: 6  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Recast the requirement “fraction = 1/11” into the equivalent condition “denominator = 11 × numerator,” so the task becomes finding a single number N (built from some of the digits) whose product with 11 uses exactly the remaining digits.  
2. (Creative) Note a key property of multiplication by 11: the units digit of 11 × N is the same as the units digit of N. Therefore, the numerator and denominator must end with the same digit.  
3. (Rudimentary) List the possible shared units digits from the multiset {1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 4, 4, 5, 7} and, for each choice, set aside that digit for both numerator and denominator.  
4. (Rudimentary) For each candidate units digit, systematically arrange the remaining digits into trial numerators N and check whether 11 × N produces a five-digit number that (a) uses exactly the leftover digits and (b) ends with the chosen units digit.  
5. (Rudimentary) Find that selecting N = 4321 works, because 11 × 4321 = 47531, and the multiset of digits {4, 3, 2, 1, 4, 7, 5, 3, 1} matches the original set.  
6. (Rudimentary) Conclude that 4321⁄47531 = 1⁄11 satisfies the problem’s requirement, presenting 4321/47531 as a valid arrangement.

Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Recast the requirement “fraction = 1/11” into the equivalent condition “denominator = 11 × numerator,” so the task becomes finding a single number N (built from some of the digits) whose product with 11 uses exactly the remaining digits.  
2. (Creative) Note a key property of multiplication by 11: the units digit of 11 × N is the same as the units digit of N. Therefore, the numerator and denominator must end with the same digit.  
3. (Rudimentary) List the possible shared units digits from the multiset {1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 4, 4, 5, 7} and, for each choice, set aside that digit for both numerator and denominator.  
4. (Rudimentary) For each candidate units digit, systematically arrange the remaining digits into trial numerators N and check whether 11 × N produces a five-digit number that (a) uses exactly the leftover digits and (b) ends with the chosen units digit.  
5. (Rudimentary) Find that selecting N = 4321 works, because 11 × 4321 = 47531, and the multiset of digits {4, 3, 2, 1, 4, 7, 5, 3, 1} matches the original set.  
6. (Rudimentary) Conclude that 4321⁄47531 = 1⁄11 satisfies the problem’s requirement, presenting 4321/47531 as a valid arrangement.']

Question: How many trailing zeros are in the number 1000!?
Hint: The number of trailing zeros is equivalent to the number of factors of 10
Human Solution:
The ! stands for factorial.  So, there are exactly 249 trailing zeros in 1000!
The only way to get a trailing zero is by multiplying a factor of 1000! which is 2 by a factor of 1000! which is 5. The modified problem is thus: How many such pairs of factors are there?
There are 500 = 1000/2 numbers between 1 and 1000 (inclusive) which are even, so there are at least 500 factors of 2 in 1000!. There are 200 = 1000/5 numbers which are multiples of 5. But in addition there are 40 = 1000/25 numbers which are multiples of 25, each of which gives one factor of five in addition to the one counted in the 200 and the one counted in the 40 above. Finally there is 1 = [1000/625] number which is a multiple of 625, this gives one further factor of 5. Thus there are exactly  200 + 40 + 8 + 1 = 249 factors of 5 in 1000! and since there are more than sufficient factors of 2, there are exactly 249 trailing zeros in 1000!
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. Creative – Recognize that each trailing zero in a decimal number comes from a factor 10 = 2 × 5 in the prime factorization of 1000!.  
2. Creative – Note that 1000! contains far more factors 2 than factors 5, so the total number of trailing zeros equals the number of factors 5.  
3. Rudimentary – Count the numbers ≤ 1000 divisible by 5: ⌊1000/5⌋ = 200, giving 200 factors 5.  
4. Rudimentary – Count the additional factors 5 from multiples of 25: ⌊1000/25⌋ = 40 extra factors.  
5. Rudimentary – Count the additional factors 5 from multiples of 125: ⌊1000/125⌋ = 8 extra factors.  
6. Rudimentary – Count the additional factors 5 from multiples of 625: ⌊1000/625⌋ = 1 extra factor.  
7. Rudimentary – Add all factors 5: 200 + 40 + 8 + 1 = 249.  
8. Rudimentary – Conclude that 1000! has 249 trailing zeros because each of the 249 factors 5 pairs with a factor 2 to form 249 factors 10.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 8  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. Creative – Recognize that each trailing zero in a decimal number comes from a factor 10 = 2 × 5 in the prime factorization of 1000!.  
2. Creative – Note that 1000! contains far more factors 2 than factors 5, so the total number of trailing zeros equals the number of factors 5.  
3. Rudimentary – Count the numbers ≤ 1000 divisible by 5: ⌊1000/5⌋ = 200, giving 200 factors 5.  
4. Rudimentary – Count the additional factors 5 from multiples of 25: ⌊1000/25⌋ = 40 extra factors.  
5. Rudimentary – Count the additional factors 5 from multiples of 125: ⌊1000/125⌋ = 8 extra factors.  
6. Rudimentary – Count the additional factors 5 from multiples of 625: ⌊1000/625⌋ = 1 extra factor.  
7. Rudimentary – Add all factors 5: 200 + 40 + 8 + 1 = 249.  
8. Rudimentary – Conclude that 1000! has 249 trailing zeros because each of the 249 factors 5 pairs with a factor 2 to form 249 factors 10.']

Question:
In a 14-stage cycle race there were a 100 competitors, among them "Crazy" Charles
In all 14 stages "Crazy" Charles finished in the same position: 93rd. However, at the end of the race, "Crazy" Charles was declared runner-up in the competition: his accumulated time was less than that of all the other competitors except one, the champion.
Bearing in mind the fact that none of the 100 competitors withdrew from the race, how was it possible for "Crazy" Charles to finish second if he never even made it into the top 90 competitors?
Hint: Find the maximum number of people he can beat--as time is aggregated, note that one can finish in a shorter time than someone else overall
Human Solution: "Crazy" Charles was runner-up in the race because in each of the 14 stages he beat 7 different competitors, and he beat them all by more time than the accumulated time that they beat him by in all the other stages of the tour. Since 7*14=98, there was only one cyclist that he never beat and that was the champion.
Response:
Total Step Count: 6  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Note that finishing 93rd in a 100-rider field means Charles finishes ahead of exactly 7 riders (those in 94th–100th place) in every stage. [Rudimentary]  

2. Realize that if the seven riders Charles beats in each stage are chosen to be different from stage to stage, then over 14 stages he can finish ahead of 7 × 14 = 98 distinct riders. [Creative]  

3. Arrange the stage results so that indeed the set of seven riders Charles beats in each stage is disjoint from the sets in the other stages, leaving only one rider (the future champion) whom he never beats. [Rudimentary]  

4. Make the time gaps large enough so that, for every rider Charles beats in his one “good” stage against that rider, the single time gain he earns is larger than the total time he loses to that rider in the other 13 stages. [Creative]  

5. Conclude that Charles’ accumulated time is therefore smaller than the total time of each of those 98 riders. [Rudimentary]  

6. Since the only rider he never beats can still have an even smaller total time, that rider becomes the champion and Charles, faster than everyone else, is declared the runner-up. [Rudimentary]
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 6  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Note that finishing 93rd in a 100-rider field means Charles finishes ahead of exactly 7 riders (those in 94th–100th place) in every stage. [Rudimentary]  

2. Realize that if the seven riders Charles beats in each stage are chosen to be different from stage to stage, then over 14 stages he can finish ahead of 7 × 14 = 98 distinct riders. [Creative]  

3. Arrange the stage results so that indeed the set of seven riders Charles beats in each stage is disjoint from the sets in the other stages, leaving only one rider (the future champion) whom he never beats. [Rudimentary]  

4. Make the time gaps large enough so that, for every rider Charles beats in his one “good” stage against that rider, the single time gain he earns is larger than the total time he loses to that rider in the other 13 stages. [Creative]  

5. Conclude that Charles’ accumulated time is therefore smaller than the total time of each of those 98 riders. [Rudimentary]  

6. Since the only rider he never beats can still have an even smaller total time, that rider becomes the champion and Charles, faster than everyone else, is declared the runner-up. [Rudimentary]']

Question: The Boldavian navy has a rigorous training program.  In order to graduate from the naval academy, cadets must enter a pool and fight sharks.  Today, a group of cadets was tested.  Each cadet put on his mask, snorkel, and two flippers; and armed himself with a knife.  Then the cadets jumped into the pool.  The sharks were then released from their pens.  After 10 minutes of gruelling hand-to-fin combat, all of the sharks were killed.  Miraculously, none of the cadets were killed.  Exiting the pool, the cadets began to haul the shark bodies out of the water.  The dead sharks were soon lying in a row.  One of the cadets noted that during the fight, there were 4 times as many cadets in the water as there were sharks.  A second cadet then stated that the number of legs they now had was equal to the square of the number of sharks.  A third said that the number of cadet legs was 14 more than the total number of cadet and shark heads.  How many sharks were killed?
Hint: Set up systems of equations; notice that legs could be lost ("they now had")
Human Solution:
7 sharks were killed.
Since there were 4 times as many cadets, there were 28 cadets.  The number of cadet legs is equal to the square of the number of sharks, which would be 49 legs.  49 legs is 14 more than the number of cadet and shark heads: 7 sharks plus 28 cadets equals 35 heads.
Note that although all of the cadets survived, nothing was said about possible injuries.  In fact, each shark had bitten off one leg from each of 7 cadets.  This explains the shortage of legs, since 28 cadets should have had 56 legs, not 49.  Also note the statement of the second cadet, who said 'the number of legs they NOW had ...'.
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) Let S represent the number of sharks killed.  
2. (Rudimentary) Use the stated 4 : 1 ratio to express the number of cadets as 4S.  
3. (Rudimentary) Note that every shark and every cadet has one head, so the total number of heads is S + 4S = 5S.  
4. (Rudimentary) Translate the second cadet’s remark: the current number of cadet legs equals the square of the number of sharks, giving cadet-leg count S².  
5. (Rudimentary) Translate the third cadet’s remark: the cadet-leg count is 14 more than the total number of heads, giving the equation S² = 5S + 14.  
6. (Rudimentary) Solve S² – 5S – 14 = 0 to obtain the positive solution S = 7.  
7. (Rudimentary) Compute derived quantities: 4·7 = 28 cadets; intact cadets would have 56 legs, but the statement says they now have only 49 legs, showing a loss of 7 legs.  
8. (Creative) Provide the explanatory insight: each of the 7 sharks must have bitten off exactly one cadet leg, accounting for the discrepancy and justifying the word “now” in the second cadet’s statement.

Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 7

5. (Rudimentary) Translate the third cadet’s remark: the cadet-leg count is 14 more than the total number of heads, giving the equation S² = 5S + 14.

8. (Creative) Provide the explanatory insight: each of the 7 sharks must have bitten off exactly one cadet leg, accounting for the discrepancy and justifying the word “now” in the second cadet’s statement.']

Question:
There is a five digit square number that is palindromic, and each digit is also a nonzero square number.
What is it?
Hint: Of course, it must be the square of a palindromic number. Therefore, when you multiply its square root by itself, there's no carrying, because carrying will break the palindrome. And therefore...
Response:
Total Step Count: 2  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 1  

Steps:  
1. Select the palindromic five-digit number 44944 whose digits (4, 4, 9, 4, 4) are each non-zero perfect squares. (Creative)  
2. Confirm that 44944 is a perfect square by showing 212² = 44944. (Rudimentary)

Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 1  

Steps:  
1. Select the palindromic five-digit number 44944 whose digits (4, 4, 9, 4, 4) are each non-zero perfect squares. (Creative)  
2. Confirm that 44944 is a perfect square by showing 212² = 44944. (Rudimentary)']

Question: The owner of a Romankachi flower boutique follows a particular pattern for his business. During a period of inflation, he raises his prices by Y% and during a slowdown he decreases his existing prices by Y%. After a year in which there was inflation first, followed by a slowdown, the cost of a Red Rose bouquet  decreases by 162 Roka (Roka being the native Romankachi currency). After another year in which there was inflation once more followed by a slowdown, the cost of this bouquet reduces by a further 147.42 Roka. What was the original price of the  Red Rose bouquet ?
Hint: Everything can be expressed and solvd in terms of the original price of the bouquet and the inflation rate
Human Solution:
The original price of the  Red Rose bouquet is 1800 Roka.
Let the original price of the Red Rose bouquet  be 'B' Roka.
It is given that during a period of inflation, he raises his prices by Y% and during a slowdown he decreases his existing prices by Y%.
Hence after a year in which there was inflation first, followed by a slowdown, and the cost of a Red Rose bouquet decreased by 162 Roka, the price of the bouquet
= B(1+Y)(1-Y)
= B(1-Y^2)
(since B(1+Y) is the price during inflation and  B(1-Y)(1+Y) the price during the slowdown)
Therefore the decrease in price after one year
= B - B(1-Y^2)
= B - B + B*Y^2
= B*Y^2 = 162      ... Equation 1
Hence after another year in which there was inflation first, followed by a slowdown, and the cost of a Red Rose bouquet decreased by 147.42 Roka, the price of the bouquet
= B(1-Y^2)(1+Y)(1-Y)
= B(1-Y^2)(1-Y^2)
= B(1-Y^2)^2
(since B(1-Y^2) is the price at the end of the previous year and           B(1-Y^2)(1+Y)(1-Y) the price during the slowdown this year)
Therefore the decrease in price this year
= B(1-Y^2) - B(1-Y^2)^2
= B(1-Y^2)[1 - (1-Y^2)]
= B(1-Y^2)( Y^2) = 147.42    ... Equation 2
Dividing Equation 2 by Equation 1, we get
(1-Y^2) = 0.91 => Y^2 = 0.09
Substituting the above value of Y^2 in equation 1, we get
B*0.09 = 162
Hence B = 162/0.09 = 1800 Roka.
Therefore the original price of the  Red Rose bouquet is 1800 Roka.
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. Introduce a variable, letting the original bouquet price be B Roka. (Rudimentary)  
2. Model one cycle of “inflate by Y %, then cut by Y %” as a single multiplication by (1+Y)(1−Y)=1−Y², giving the post-cycle price B(1−Y²). (Creative)  
3. Set up the first-year drop: original price minus post-cycle price equals BY² = 162, and record this as Equation 1. (Rudimentary)  
4. Apply the same (1−Y²) factor to the new base price to express the end-of-second-year price as B(1−Y²)². (Rudimentary)  
5. Write the second-year drop as B(1−Y²) − B(1−Y²)² = B(1−Y²)Y² = 147.42, giving Equation 2. (Rudimentary)  
6. Divide Equation 2 by Equation 1 to eliminate B Y², obtaining 1−Y² = 0.91 and hence Y² = 0.09. (Rudimentary)  
7. Substitute Y² = 0.09 into Equation 1 to solve for B: 0.09 B = 162 ⇒ B = 1800 Roka. (Rudimentary)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 7  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 6

1. Introduce a variable, letting the original bouquet price be B Roka. (Rudimentary)  
2. Model one cycle of “inflate by Y %, then cut by Y %” as a single multiplication by (1+Y)(1−Y)=1−Y², giving the post-cycle price B(1−Y²). (Creative)  
3. Set up the first-year drop: original price minus post-cycle price equals BY² = 162, and record this as Equation 1. (Rudimentary)  
4. Apply the same (1−Y²) factor to the new base price to express the end-of-second-year price as B(1−Y²)². (Rudimentary)  
5. Write the second-year drop as B(1−Y²) − B(1−Y²)² = B(1−Y²)Y² = 147.42, giving Equation 2. (Rudimentary)

7. Substitute Y² = 0.09 into Equation 1 to solve for B: 0.09 B = 162 ⇒ B = 1800 Roka. (Rudimentary)']

Question: There is a 2x3 checkerboard with 6 unit squares that are labeled as 1 through 6. If we are going to divide it into at least two rectangles whose sides are all integers, how many different ways are there?
Hint: Since the cells are labeled, ways that are the same upon reflection or symmetry are considered different ways.
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary) List every rectangle size that can fit inside a 2 × 3 board: 1 × 1 (area 1), 1 × 2 / 2 × 1 (area 2), 1 × 3 (area 3), 2 × 2 (area 4), and the whole 2 × 3 (area 6). Discard the area-6 rectangle because at least two rectangles are required.  

2. (Creative) Re-express the tiling problem as “partition the total area 6 into a multiset of the admissible areas found in Step 1.” This converts a spatial tiling question into a finite list of integer partitions that must be examined.  

3. (Rudimentary) Enumerate all such partitions and group them by how many rectangles they contain:  
   • 2 rectangles: 4 + 2, 3 + 3  
   • 3 rectangles: 4 + 1 + 1, 3 + 2 + 1, 2 + 2 + 2  
   • 4 rectangles: 3 + 1 + 1 + 1, 2 + 2 + 1 + 1  
   • 5 rectangles: 2 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1  
   • 6 rectangles: 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1  

4. (Rudimentary) For each partition, count by direct inspection (drawing or systematic checking) how many distinct geometric tilings of the 2 × 3 board realize that multiset of rectangle areas, obtaining:  
   2 for 4 + 2,  
   1 for 3 + 3,  
   2 for 4 + 1 + 1,  
   4 for 3 + 2 + 1,  
   3 for 2 + 2 + 2,  
   2 for 3 + 1 + 1 + 1,  
   11 for 2 + 2 + 1 + 1,  
   7 for 2 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1,  
   1 for six 1 × 1’s.  

5. (Rudimentary) Add all of the individual counts from Step 4 to obtain the grand total 33 distinct tilings.

Rudimentary Steps: 4

2. (Creative) Re-express the tiling problem as “partition the total area 6 into a multiset of the admissible areas found in Step 1.” This converts a spatial tiling question into a finite list of integer partitions that must be examined.  

3. (Rudimentary) Enumerate all such partitions and group them by how many rectangles they contain:  
   • 2 rectangles: 4 + 2, 3 + 3  
   • 3 rectangles: 4 + 1 + 1, 3 + 2 + 1, 2 + 2 + 2  
   • 4 rectangles: 3 + 1 + 1 + 1, 2 + 2 + 1 + 1  
   • 5 rectangles: 2 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1  
   • 6 rectangles: 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1  

4. (Rudimentary) For each partition, count by direct inspection (drawing or systematic checking) how many distinct geometric tilings of the 2 × 3 board realize that multiset of rectangle areas, obtaining:

5. (Rudimentary) Add all of the individual counts from Step 4 to obtain the grand total 33 distinct tilings.']

Question:
In our business, my two partners and I usually cut a lot of cake. However, when we get a last minute cancellation, we sometimes look for new and unusual ways to cut small amounts of cake.
On one such occasion, we tried to find a cake with an unusual set of attributes.
First, it had to be a regular polygon, i.e. all sides equal in length and all angles equal in size.
Second, using only standard cuts (straight and perpendicular to the plate) from some corner to another, we would be able to exactly divide that polygon into equal portions.
Third, except for the last cut, each cut would create one, and only one, such portion.  The last cut would create two such portions.
Fourth, there must be more than two portions. (Otherwise, a square or any regular polygon with an even number of sides would do. A cut from one corner to its opposing corner would carve out two pieces of 50% each.)
For discussion purposes, we decided to label the points of our polygons alphabetically.  A pentagon can only produce three pieces. Triangles ABC and CDE are equals, but triangle ACE is larger. A hexagon yields three or four pieces, but they will be of two different sizes.  Triangles ABC = CDE = EFA <> ACE, or triangles ABC = DEF <> CDF = FAC.  Etc.
About this time, Junior, our partner-in-waiting, said, "Cousins, I can do this, and I'll get to take a share of the cake."
Knowing Junior, we asked, "How big a headache is your math gonna give us?"
She answered, "I can prove it without using trig, powers, roots, or the Pythagorean Theorem."
Name the polygon she chose, tell how to divide it, and if you can, give proof the portions are equal.
Hint: Junior's proof uses fact that all dimensions of an isosceles right triangle are determined by its name and the length of its hypotenuse.
Human Solution:
Junior knew an octagon would sequentially yield four quarters.
After labeling the points of a perfect octagon, Junior told us, "Before I cut the cake, I'll give the proof. First, I mark a line from A to D.  This creates a trapezoid (trapezium in Britain) ABCD.  Next, I mark the lines EH, BG, and CF.  These four lines crosshatch the area dividing it into 1 square surrounded by 4 equal triangles and 4 equal rectangles."
The partners (me included) chimed in with the rest of these observations: The sides of the square are the same length as those of the octagon. Dividing the central square into isosceles right triangles (by marking both of its diagonals) would yield 4 triangles equivalent to the first 4. The total area of the octagon can be accounted for by 8 equal triangles and 4 equal rectangles.   Because it is made of 2 triangles and 1 rectangle, trapezoid ABCD is 1/4 of the octagon. A second trapezoid taken from the irregular hexagon ADEFGH will equal 1/4 of the octagon and leave 1/2 of the original octagon in the shape of a rectangle or a kite, either of which is easily split to provide the last two 1/4's. (The second and third cuts can be made in reverse order.)
...
The pieces from two arrangements follow:
1) ABCD, DEFG, ADH, and DGH.
2) ABCD, EFGH, ADH, and DEH.
Response:
Total Step Count: 10  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Recognise that a regular octagon is the smallest regular polygon that can satisfy all of Junior’s cutting requirements and therefore select it as the cake’s shape.  

2. (Rudimentary) Label the octagon’s consecutive vertices A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H to make later references clear.  

3. (Creative) Plan the first cut from vertex A to vertex D; this single diagonal immediately produces a trapezoid ABCD and an irregular hexagon ADEFGH, setting up a symmetrical way to take out a quarter of the cake at once.  

4. (Creative) Introduce auxiliary lines EH, BG, and CF (not actual cuts) together with AD to “cross-hatch” the octagon, revealing a central square, four congruent corner triangles and four congruent edge-rectangles; this geometric insight turns the area problem into simple counting.  

5. (Rudimentary) Observe that the central square’s sides equal one edge of the octagon and that the four corner triangles are congruent to one another, as are the four edge-rectangles.  

6. (Rudimentary) Draw both diagonals of the central square to split it into four more triangles congruent to the first four, so the whole octagon is now seen as 8 equal triangles + 4 equal rectangles (12 equal “area-units”).  

7. (Rudimentary) Note that trapezoid ABCD contains exactly 2 of the 8 triangles and 1 of the 4 rectangles—3 of the 12 equal units—so its area is 3⁄12 = 1⁄4 of the octagon.  

8. (Rudimentary) Choose a second, congruent trapezoid (for example DEFG) from the remaining hexagon with a second vertex-to-vertex cut, removing another 1⁄4 of the cake.  

9. (Rudimentary) Recognise that the shape left over is half the octagon (either a rectangle or a kite) and that a final straight vertex-to-vertex cut splits this remainder into two equal quarters, completing the division while satisfying the “last cut creates two equal pieces” rule.  

10. (Rudimentary) List sample sets of resulting quarters, e.g.  
    • ABCD, DEFG, ADH, DGH  
    • ABCD, EFGH, ADH, DEH,  
    to illustrate that the three-cut procedure indeed yields four equal portions.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 10  
Creative ', ' 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Recognise that a regular octagon is the smallest regular polygon that can satisfy all of Junior’s cutting requirements and therefore select it as the cake’s shape.  

2. (Rudimentary) Label the octagon’s consecutive vertices A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H to make later references clear.  

3. (Creative) Plan the first cut from vertex A to vertex D; this single diagonal immediately produces a trapezoid ABCD and an irregular hexagon ADEFGH, setting up a symmetrical way to take out a quarter of the cake at once.  

4. (Creative) Introduce auxiliary lines EH, BG, and CF (not actual cuts) together with AD to “cross-hatch” the octagon, revealing a central square, four congruent corner triangles and four congruent edge-rectangles; this geometric insight turns the area problem into simple counting.  

5. (Rudimentary) Observe that the central square’s sides equal one edge of the octagon and that the four corner triangles are congruent to one another, as are the four edge-rectangles.  

6. (Rudimentary) Draw both diagonals of the central square to split it into four more triangles congruent to the first four, so the whole octagon is now seen as 8 equal triangles + 4 equal rectangles (12 equal “area-units”).

8. (Rudimentary) Choose a second, congruent trapezoid (for example DEFG) from the remaining hexagon with a second vertex-to-vertex cut, removing another 1⁄4 of the cake.  

9. (Rudimentary) Recognise that the shape left over is half the octagon (either a rectangle or a kite) and that a final straight vertex-to-vertex cut splits this remainder into two equal quarters, completing the division while satisfying the “last cut creates two equal pieces” rule.  

10. (Rudimentary) List sample sets of resulting quarters, e.g.  
    • ABCD, DEFG, ADH, DGH  
    • ABCD, EFGH, ADH, DEH,  
    to illustrate that the three-cut procedure indeed yields four equal portions.']

Question: A solid wooden cuboid is made which measures an exact, and even, number of centimetres along each of its edges. It is then painted black all over its exposed faces and, when the paint is dry, the cuboid is cut up into 1 centimetre cubes. These small cubes are counted and it is then found that the number having NO paint on them at all, is exactly the same as the number which do have some paint on them. What is the LEAST number of small cubes there could be in total?
Hint: Basically, the volume of the cuboid is double the volume of the cuboid with each dimension decreased by 2
Human Solution: Least is 960 (8 by 10 by 12)
Response:
Total Step Count: 1  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 0  

Steps:  
1. State that the minimum possible number of 1 cm³ cubes is 960, which can be achieved with a cuboid measuring 8 cm × 10 cm × 12 cm.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 1  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 0  

Steps:  
1. State that the minimum possible number of 1 cm³ cubes is 960, which can be achieved with a cuboid measuring 8 cm × 10 cm × 12 cm.']

Question: Find three numbers, all under 500, where the sum of all three is a perfect square and the sums of any two of them are also perfect squares.
Hint: For more convenient differences, some of the numbers might be smaller
Response:
Total Step Count: 12  
Creative Steps: 5  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. Translate the verbal requirements into algebra: look for positive integers a, b, c (< 500) and integers p, q, r, s so that  
   a + b = p², a + c = q², b + c = r², a + b + c = s².  (Creative)

2. Observe that the total sum a + b + c equals s² and also equals (a + b) + c = p² + c.  
   Hence c = s² − p².  (Rudimentary)

3. By the same reasoning derive a = s² − r² and b = s² − q².  (Rudimentary)

4. Conclude that s must be strictly larger than p, q, r so that the three differences above are positive.  (Rudimentary)

5. Rewrite each difference as a difference of squares:  
   s² − p² = (s − p)(s + p), etc.  
   Notice these are automatically even and give a compact way to keep the values under 500.  (Creative)

6. Decide to search for small square numbers s² with several other, slightly smaller, square numbers nearby so that all three differences stay below 500.  (Rudimentary)

7. Notice that s = 21 works well because the nearby squares 20², 19², 11² lie on both sides of it and keep the forthcoming differences modest:  
   21² = 441, 20² = 400, 19² = 361, 11² = 121.  (Creative)

8. Compute a = s² − r² = 441 − 400 = 41.  (Rudimentary)

9. Compute b = s² − q² = 441 − 121 = 320.  (Rudimentary)

10. Compute c = s² − p² = 441 − 361 = 80.  (Rudimentary)

11. Verify every pairwise sum is a perfect square:  
    a + b = 41 + 320 = 361 = 19²,  
    a + c = 41 + 80 = 121 = 11²,  
    b + c = 320 + 80 = 400 = 20².  (Rudimentary)

12. Verify the total sum a + b + c = 41 + 320 + 80 = 441 = 21².  
    All conditions are satisfied, so the required numbers are 41, 80, 320.  (Creative)

Creative ', ' 5  
Rudimentary Steps: 7

   a + b = p², a + c = q², b + c = r², a + b + c = s².  (Creative)

2. Observe that the total sum a + b + c equals s² and also equals (a + b) + c = p² + c.  
   Hence c = s² − p².  (Rudimentary)

3. By the same reasoning derive a = s² − r² and b = s² − q².  (Rudimentary)

4. Conclude that s must be strictly larger than p, q, r so that the three differences above are positive.  (Rudimentary)

7. Notice that s = 21 works well because the nearby squares 20², 19², 11² lie on both sides of it and keep the forthcoming differences modest:  
   21² = 441, 20² = 400, 19² = 361, 11² = 121.  (Creative)

8. Compute a = s² − r² = 441 − 400 = 41.  (Rudimentary)

9. Compute b = s² − q² = 441 − 121 = 320.  (Rudimentary)

    a + b = 41 + 320 = 361 = 19²,  
    a + c = 41 + 80 = 121 = 11²,  
    b + c = 320 + 80 = 400 = 20².  (Rudimentary)

12. Verify the total sum a + b + c = 41 + 320 + 80 = 441 = 21².

Question:
Mad Ade noticed that he could arrange the five odd digits (1,3,5,7,9) into a five-digit number, such that the first two digits (as a 2-digit number) times the last two digits (as a 2-digit number) minus the center digit results in a number composed of repetitions of one digit.
Mad Ade noted there were two possible answers.
What are they?
Hint: The repeated digit must be even
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 4  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1.  Set the five-digit arrangement as ABCDE, interpret AB and DE as two–digit numbers, and translate the condition into the equation  
   AB × DE – C = DDDD (a four–digit repdigit).  (Rudimentary)

2.  Observe that AB and DE are both odd, so AB × DE is odd; subtracting the odd centre digit C yields an even result. Therefore the repdigit must consist of an even digit.  (Creative)

3.  Conclude the only possible repdigits are 2222, 4444, 6666, or 8888 (0000 is impossible and 1111, 3333, 5555, 7777, 9999 are odd).  (Rudimentary)

4.  Note the numerical range of AB × DE: the smallest product 13 × 57 = 741 and the largest 97 × 95 = 9 215, so all four even repdigits are within reach.  (Rudimentary)

5.  Rewrite the requirement for each candidate repdigit:  
   AB × DE = 2222 + C, or 4444 + C, or 6666 + C, or 8888 + C, where C ∈ {1,3,5,7,9}.  (Rudimentary)

6.  Check the first case (2222): look for a factorisation of any number from 2223 to 2239 using two distinct odd two-digit numbers made from {1,3,5,7,9}. Discover that 2223 = 39 × 57, which uses only the allowed digits.  (Creative)

7.  Allocate the unused digit 1 as the centre digit C; verify 39 × 57 – 1 = 2222, giving the number 39157.  (Rudimentary)

8.  Swap the two factors to get 57 × 39 – 1 = 2222, yielding the second valid arrangement 57139.  Rudimentary)

9.  Confirm that no other candidate repdigit (4444, 6666, 8888) admits a factorisation with the remaining digits, so the two found numbers are the only solutions.  (Creative)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 9  
Creative ', ' 4  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1.  Set the five-digit arrangement as ABCDE, interpret AB and DE as two–digit numbers, and translate the condition into the equation  
   AB × DE – C = DDDD (a four–digit repdigit).  (Rudimentary)

2.  Observe that AB and DE are both odd, so AB × DE is odd; subtracting the odd centre digit C yields an even result. Therefore the repdigit must consist of an even digit.  (Creative)

3.  Conclude the only possible repdigits are 2222, 4444, 6666, or 8888 (0000 is impossible and 1111, 3333, 5555, 7777, 9999 are odd).  (Rudimentary)

4.  Note the numerical range of AB × DE: the smallest product 13 × 57 = 741 and the largest 97 × 95 = 9 215, so all four even repdigits are within reach.  (Rudimentary)

5.  Rewrite the requirement for each candidate repdigit:  
   AB × DE = 2222 + C, or 4444 + C, or 6666 + C, or 8888 + C, where C ∈ {1,3,5,7,9}.  (Rudimentary)

6.  Check the first case (2222): look for a factorisation of any number from 2223 to 2239 using two distinct odd two-digit numbers made from {1,3,5,7,9}. Discover that 2223 = 39 × 57, which uses only the allowed digits.  (Creative)

7.  Allocate the unused digit 1 as the centre digit C; verify 39 × 57 – 1 = 2222, giving the number 39157.  (Rudimentary)

8.  Swap the two factors to get 57 × 39 – 1 = 2222, yielding the second valid arrangement 57139.  Rudimentary)

9.  Confirm that no other candidate repdigit (4444, 6666, 8888) admits a factorisation with the remaining digits, so the two found numbers are the only solutions.  (Creative)']

Question:
Old Farmer McDoughnut owns a piece of grassland in the heart of Madadia and has three animals: a Madadian Burger Cow, a Spare Kebab Goat, and a Scotch Egg laying Goose. McDoughnut discovered the following:
When the cow and the goat graze on the field together, there is no more grass after 45 days.
When the cow and the goose graze on the field together, there is no more grass after 60 days.
When the cow grazes on the field alone, there is no more grass after 90 days.
When the goat and the goose graze on the field together, there is no more grass after 90 days also.
For how long can the three animals graze on the field together?
Hint: Rates problem--use the same algebraic techniques
Human Solution:
The cow, the goat, and the goose eat grass with a constant speed (amount per day): v1 for the cow, v2 for the goat, v3 for the goose.
The grass grows with a constant amount per day (k).
The amount of grass at the beginning is h.
There is given:
When the cow and the goat graze on the field together, there is no grass left after 45 days. Therefore, h-45x(v1+v2-k) = 0, so v1+v2-k = h/45 = 4xh/180.
When the cow and the goose graze on the field together, there is no grass left after 60 days. Therefore, h-60x(v1+v3-k) = 0, so v1+v3-k = h/60 = 3xh/180.
When the cow grazes on the field alone, there is no grass left after 90 days. Therefore, h-90x(v1-k) = 0, so v1-k = h/90 = 2xh/180.
When the goat and the goose graze on the field together, there is also no grass left after 90 days. Therefore, h-90x(v2+v3-k) = 0, so v2+v3-k = h/90 = 2xh/180.
From this follows:
v1 = 3 x h/180,
v2 = 2 x h/180,
v3 = 1 x h/180,
k = 1 x h/180.
Then holds for the time t that the three animals can graze together: h-tx(v1+v2+v3-k) = 0, so t = h/(v1+v2+v3-k) = h/(3xh/180+2xh/180+1xh/180-1xh/180) = 36. The three animals can graze together for 36 days.
Response:
Total Step Count: 6  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Creative –  Set up the mathematical model: assign variables v₁, v₂, v₃ for the daily grass-eating rates of the cow, goat, and goose; k for the daily grass-growth rate; and h for the initial amount of grass.  
2. Rudimentary –  Translate each grazing scenario into an equation of the form h – T · (sum of eating rates – k) = 0, producing:  
   • v₁ + v₂ – k = h/45  
   • v₁ + v₃ – k = h/60  
   • v₁ – k = h/90  
   • v₂ + v₃ – k = h/90  
3. Rudimentary –  Rewrite the right-hand sides with a common denominator (180) for easier comparison:  
   • v₁ + v₂ – k = 4h/180, etc.  
4. Rudimentary –  Solve the linear system to find each unknown rate in terms of h:  
   v₁ = 3h/180, v₂ = 2h/180, v₃ = h/180, k = h/180.  
5. Rudimentary –  Write the depletion equation for all three animals grazing together: h – t · (v₁ + v₂ + v₃ – k) = 0.  
6. Rudimentary –  Substitute the values of v₁, v₂, v₃, and k, simplify, and solve for t to obtain t = 36 days.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 6  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Creative –  Set up the mathematical model: assign variables v₁, v₂, v₃ for the daily grass-eating rates of the cow, goat, and goose; k for the daily grass-growth rate; and h for the initial amount of grass.  
2. Rudimentary –  Translate each grazing scenario into an equation of the form h – T · (sum of eating rates – k) = 0, producing:  
   • v₁ + v₂ – k = h/45  
   • v₁ + v₃ – k = h/60  
   • v₁ – k = h/90  
   • v₂ + v₃ – k = h/90  
3. Rudimentary –  Rewrite the right-hand sides with a common denominator (180) for easier comparison:  
   • v₁ + v₂ – k = 4h/180, etc.  
4. Rudimentary –  Solve the linear system to find each unknown rate in terms of h:  
   v₁ = 3h/180, v₂ = 2h/180, v₃ = h/180, k = h/180.  
5. Rudimentary –  Write the depletion equation for all three animals grazing together: h – t · (v₁ + v₂ + v₃ – k) = 0.  
6. Rudimentary –  Substitute the values of v₁, v₂, v₃, and k, simplify, and solve for t to obtain t = 36 days.']

Question: n people each know a different piece of gossip. They can telephone each other and exchange all the information they know (so that after the call they both know anything that either of them knew before the call). What is the smallest number of calls needed so that everyone knows everything?
Hint: Assign a "core group" that collectively reaches out to the rest of the group
Human Solution:
1 for n=2
3 for n=3
2n-4 for n>=4
This can be achieved as follows: choose four people (A, B, C, and D) as the "core group". Each person outside the core group phones a member of the core group (it doesn't matter which); this takes n-4 calls. Now the core group makes 4 calls: A-B, C-D, A-C, and B-D. At this point, each member of the core group knows everything. Now, each person outside the core group calls anybody who knows everything; this again requires n-4 calls, for a total of 2n-4.
Response:
Total Step Count: 6  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Note the trivial optimal values: 1 call suffices when n = 2, and 3 calls suffice when n = 3. (Rudimentary)  
2. For n ≥ 4, introduce the key idea of designating four people (A, B, C, D) as a “core group” that will first consolidate all gossip. (Creative)  
3. Phase 1: Have each of the remaining n − 4 people place a single call to any member of the core group, thereby funneling their gossip into the core. This costs n − 4 calls. (Rudimentary)  
4. Phase 2: Use the specific four-call pattern A–B, C–D, A–C, B–D inside the core so that, after these four calls, every core member knows every piece of gossip. (Creative)  
5. Phase 3: Each non-core person now makes one additional call to any fully informed person (e.g., any core member) to learn everything; again this takes n − 4 calls. (Rudimentary)  
6. Add the calls from all three phases: (n − 4) + 4 + (n − 4) = 2n − 4, giving the claimed minimum for n ≥ 4. (Rudimentary)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 6  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Note the trivial optimal values: 1 call suffices when n = 2, and 3 calls suffice when n = 3. (Rudimentary)  
2. For n ≥ 4, introduce the key idea of designating four people (A, B, C, D) as a “core group” that will first consolidate all gossip. (Creative)  
3. Phase 1: Have each of the remaining n − 4 people place a single call to any member of the core group, thereby funneling their gossip into the core. This costs n − 4 calls. (Rudimentary)  
4. Phase 2: Use the specific four-call pattern A–B, C–D, A–C, B–D inside the core so that, after these four calls, every core member knows every piece of gossip. (Creative)  
5. Phase 3: Each non-core person now makes one additional call to any fully informed person (e.g., any core member) to learn everything; again this takes n − 4 calls. (Rudimentary)  
6. Add the calls from all three phases: (n − 4) + 4 + (n − 4) = 2n − 4, giving the claimed minimum for n ≥ 4. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
Use all the digits from 1 to 9 to complete the equation
??? x 3? = ????
Response:
Total Step Count: 6  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Enumerate all possible two-digit numbers of the form 3? that avoid 0 and repeated digits, giving the set {31, 32, 34, 35, 36, 37, 38, 39}.  (Rudimentary)  

2. Use size considerations to bound the three-digit factor: a value in the low hundreds multiplied by 31–39 must stay below 10 000, so the first factor must lie roughly between 100 and 322.  (Creative)  

3. Observe that every digit 1–9 must appear exactly once across the three factors; hence the chosen 3? already fixes one “3” and one other digit, leaving seven distinct digits for the multiplicand and the product—this greatly narrows the search space.  (Creative)  

4. Systematically test each candidate 3? with eligible three-digit numbers in the 100–322 range, immediately discarding any trial in which digits repeat or a 0 appears.  (Rudimentary)  

5. During this testing, discover that 186 × 39 yields 7254, and verify that the combined digits {1, 8, 6, 3, 9, 7, 2, 5, 4} are exactly the set {1,…,9}.  (Rudimentary)  

6. Conclude that the required equation is 186 × 39 = 7254.  (Rudimentary)
